Report.name: AGE-WELL Emerging Entrepreneur Award (2020) COVID-19 Countermeasures

ReportSection.tooltip: AGE-WELL Emerging Entrepreneur Award (2020) COVID-19 Countermeasures
ReportSection.name: Background Information
ReportSection.title: AGE-WELL Emerging Entrepreneur Award (2020) COVID-19 Countermeasures
ReportSection.Static:
About AGE-WELL

AGE-WELL NCE is Canada’s Technology and Aging Network. The pan-Canadian network brings together researchers, older adults, caregivers, partner organizations and future leaders to accelerate the delivery of technology-based solutions that make a meaningful difference in the lives of Canadians. AGE-WELL researchers are producing technologies, services, policies and practices that improve quality of life for older adults and caregivers, and generate social and economic benefits for Canada.

Description

The 2020 Emerging Entrepreneur Award is part of AGE-WELL’s effort to address the public health challenges associated with the novel coronavirus pandemic. The rapid spread of COVID-19 has highlighted especially the vulnerability of Canada’s older adults and the potential impact of technological innovations to mitigate the spread of disease and minimize its disruptive impact on health and fulfillment of psychosocial needs.

This $25,000 award is designed to give a new entrepreneur the financial resources to focus on making their ideas viable and rapidly deployable in service to our stakeholders.

Applicants to this call of the AGE-WELL Emerging Entrepreneur Award must clearly communicate their innovation’s relevance as a COVID-19 countermeasure. For example, but not limited to:

  • Social isolation solutions for older adults and caregivers
  • Telehealth or remote care and relevant digital health innovations (e.g. tools that assist caregivers and/or the overall circle of care with remote care)
  • Solutions related to in-home rehabilitation or physical fitness
  • Serious games
  • Smart homes and home monitoring

Eligibility

In order to be considered for the AGE-WELL Emerging Entrepreneur Award funding applicants must:

  1. Be students, post-doctoral fellows, or have graduated/completed a post-doctoral fellowship within the last three years seeking to turn their innovation into a viable business through an existing or planned start-up company.
  2. Be over the age of 18 and residents of Canada.
  3. Innovations previously funded by AGE-WELL project grants (i.e. Core Research Project, Catalyst, SIP or CIP grants) may be supported through this program. However, applicants are unable to hold funds from two 12-month AGE-WELL funding or award programs at the same time and may hold and an Emerging Entrepreneur Award only once.
  4. Be able to commit 20+ hours per week towards developing or scaling their business.

Program Requirements

Training
Recipients will be automatically enrolled in our EPIC training program (Early Professionals, Inspired Careers) and are expected to participate actively in AGE-WELL seminar series and professional development activities (e.g. workshops in commercialization or entrepreneurship) to earn the Innovators of Tomorrow certificate.

Mentorship
Award recipients are expected to hold, at minimum, quarterly meetings with their assigned mentors to ensure ongoing progress towards project goals.

Reporting
  1. Recipients are required to complete a final report on outcomes and impact in June 2021.

Acknowledging AGE-WELL
Recipients will acknowledge the AGE-WELL Emerging Entrepreneur Award program in their presentations, publications, and other knowledge translation activities related to research conducted during their funding period. Recipients are required to use the AGE-WELL logo on their posters and other materials related to research conducted during their funding period and cooperate in the publicising of any success stories arising from this award.

Review Criteria

All applications will be reviewed by a team of field experts using the following criteria:
  • rationale and approach
  • feasibility
  • your value proposition
  • fit with AGE-WELL vision and mission

Required Documents

Award applicants must submit the following:
  1. Online Application Form
  2. Partner Letters of Support (if applicable)
  3. Curriculum Vitae

Important Dates

Applications Open: April, 2020
Completed Applications Due: 30 April, 2020
Results Available: 25 May, 2020
Funding Commences: June 2020

ReportSection.name: Application Form
ReportSection.Static:
BACKGROUND INFORMATION
Applicant Name {$user_name}
ReportSection.ReportItem: Complete only if a current student or postdoctoral fellow Academic status and Department {$item}
Supervisor Name {$item}
Institution/University {$item}

ReportItem.placeholder: e.g. PhD, Occupational therapy, University of Toronto

ReportSection.ReportItem: Complete only if not a current student or postdoctoral fellow Terminal degree received, date (month/year), department, and institution {$item}
Project Title/Company Name {$item}
Are you applying to launch a start up or support an existing company? {$item}
If you selected Support above, are you listed as a co-founder of the company? {$item}
AGE-WELL Challenge Area of best fit (max. 2) {$item}

PLAIN LANGUAGE SUMMARY Provide a 250-word plain language summary that includes a problem statement, description of innovation and its anticipated impact(s). This summary will be provided to network stakeholders in order to facilitate a Relevancy Review to determine the potential for uptake and impact if funded. This description will also be used for future communications if the proposal is successful. {$item}

RATIONALE AND APPROACH Summarize the rationale for the solution(150 words max)
  • Emerging Entrepreneur funds support entrepreneurs as they look to turn or grow their solution into a business. What is the current state of this solution and to what stage do you expect to move it during the term of this award?
{$item}

What is unique or innovative about this innovation/solution? (150 words max)
  • What sets your innovation apart?
{$item}

What is the value of the solution for older adults and/or caregivers? (200 words max)
  • What problem does this project solve?
  • What is the value proposition?
  • How have older adults or caregivers been involved or integrated in your project’s development?
{$item}

Who are your customers? What is the Market Size? (100 words max)
  • To whom will the evidence/knowledge/information/product be disseminated? Provide a sense of the size/scale of the target audience/market (in Canada and beyond).
{$item}

What are the competitive advantages of your proposed solution and who are your competitors? (200 words max)
  • Please list your top 3-5 competitive advantages.
  • Please list your top 3 competitors or existing/substitute solutions (bullet points).
  • Please explain how your solution is different.
{$item}
INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY How have you protected any intellectual property such as patents, trade secrets, copyright etc.(100 words max) {$item}
What are your needs moving forward (e.g. IP or legal support, partnerships etc.) (100 words) {$item}
PROJECT TEAM How long have you been committed to this venture? Please provide some indication of your level of commitment going forward (100 words max) {$item}
Please list all team members (you will be asked to submit curriculum vitae for each member) {$item}

Describe how the expertise of your team will contribute to the success of the proposed initiative. Identify additional skills needed to fill expertise gaps on your team, if any, and how you plan to address them (200 words max) {$item}

PARTNERSHIPS Industry and/or community partners (200 words max)

The AGE-WELL Network unites leading Canadian private and public companies, government bodies, care providers, end-users and academic partners to develop cohesive critical mass in the technology and aging sector. All AGE-WELL researchers and trainees have access to the AGE-WELL partner network. We expect that the majority of AGE-WELL funded projects will be carried out in conjunction with a community or industrial partner, for example: a technology company, a service provider, or a government department or agency.

  • Outline the partnerships involved
  • Specify how your project is aligned with partner goals, their role and contribution in the project and how you will work directly with this partner(s).
  • If your research does not currently involve working with a partner organization, identify the type of partner that would be appropriate for your project and how your project might benefit from partner engagement (e.g. Co-development of technology, knowledge mobilization, experiential learning). Where possible, AGE-WELL will attempt to link projects with appropriate AGE-WELL partners.
 {$item}
Other funding obtained/applied for {$item}
